newsitem.title: USA: Clinton urges quick action on disaster aid.
newsitem.headline: Clinton urges quick action on disaster aid.

text.p: U.S. President Bill Clinton on Thursday urged Congress to pass a bill providing disaster aid for the flooded Midwest before leaving town for a week-long Memorial Day recess.

"I urge the Congress not to leavge for Memorial Day recess without sending me a clean, emergency supplemental bill that provides the disaster assistance upon which hundreds of thousands of Americans are depending," Clinton said in a statement released by the White House late on Thursday.

Clinton's statement came after House Republican leaders tried to adjourn for the recess without approving the disaster aid, only to face a bipartisan rebellion by lawmakers dismayed at the prospect of going home to voters empty-handed.

Both parties support disaster aid, but the original $8.4 billion emergency spending bill became bogged down because of unrelated spending and environmental amendments that were added by Republicans, drawing veto threats from the president.

Clinton cited the devastation wrought by floods, mudslides and other natural disasters in 33 states and said people were counting on help from the federal government. "Congress owes it to them to pass a clean bill and send it to me for my signature," he said.

Despite days of talks, Congress and the White House have been unable to bridge their differences on the original bill, which would have provided $5.5 billion to more than 30 states hit by natural disasters, as well as about $2 billion for U.S. overseas military operations.
